name: Eupatorium perfoliatum
Relationship: Compare: Bryon.; Sepia.; nat. mur.; Chelidonium. Nyctanthes arbor-tristis (bilious fever; insatiable thirst; bitter vomiting at close of chill; also constipation of children).

Head: Vertigo; sensation of falling to left
Throbbing pain
Occipital pain after lying down, with sense of weight
Periodical headache, every third and seventh day
Pressure as if a cap of lead pressed over the whole skull
Top and back of head with pain and soreness of eyeballs
Respiratory: Hoarseness and cough, with soreness in chest; must support it
Influenza, with great soreness of muscles and bones
Chronic loose cough, chest sore; worse at night
Cough relieved by getting on hands and knees
Stomach: Vomiting and purging of bile, of green liquid several quarts at a time
Modalities: Better: by getting on hands and knees
Fever: Chill between 7 and nine am, preceded by thirst with great soreness and aching of bones
Knows chill is coming on because he cannot drink enough
Perspiration relieves all symptoms except headache
Nausea, vomiting of bile at close of chill or hot stage; throbbing headache
Mouth: Cracks in corners of mouth, yellow coated tongue, thirst
Extremities: Aching in bones of extremities with soreness of flesh
Gouty soreness and inflamed nodosities of joints, associated with headache

details: Known as Bone-set, from the prompt manner in which it relieves pain in limbs and muscles that accompanies some forms of febrile disease, like malaria and influenza. Eupatorium acts principally upon the gastrohepatic organs and bronchial mucous membrane. It is a boon in miasmatic districts, along rivers, marshes, etc., and in all conditions where there is a great deal of BONE-PAIN. Cachexia from old chronic, bilious intermittents. Worn-out constitutions from inebriety. Sluggishness of all organs and functions. Bone-pains, general and severs. Soreness. Marked periodicity. (Ars.; China; Cedron.)
